body.p: The true advantage of CICD is creating a build-test-deploy cycle which will occur automatically whenever a change is committed.
When a pull request is received, developers can preview a temporary deployment before approving the proposed changes. Approval will then trigger the full build-test-deploy cycle.

You will need:
An application to deploy.
An instance of the CICD tool installed.
The access credentials for a valid target environment.

section.title: Overview
section.p: Using the CICD tool, specify what will happen each time the application is built: which environment to deploy the application to, which tests should be run, and who should be notified of what and how that notification should be delivered. All this information is contained in a Project.

After the cycle is defined, each build will automatically deploy the app to the target environment, run the specified tests, and send relevant notifications along the way. All the developers have to do is write, commit, and build.

ol.li: Create a New Environment. This defines the deployment target.
Create a Project. This defines the target code repository and specifies build notifications.
Create Post-Deployment Actions. This defines what actions to take, usually testing, after the build is completed. (optional)
Run a Build. Building the code kicks off the whole cycle.
